number of helpful: 3 of 15 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												Boy is this game boring. It is a real life pickaxe swinging simulator combined with a simulation of wall jumping back up hundreds of feet that you have dug to constantly go back up to the surface to sell items. I found a teleporter, but that only works for so long until you dig down so far that it becomes a real chore and a burden getting back to it, especially since if you dug around a certain way you can't jump up but sometimes you can use a steam powered jump but if you are out of water you can't use it... what a mess. I couldn't afford another personal teleporter because I didn't have any more blue orbs and they are hard to come by, so it was back to wall-jumping my way back up to the teleporter to reach town. In fact, this could have been a much better game if there was a easier way to get back to town to sell your mined ore, but there isn't. I started falling asleep because about 90% of my time was spent wall jumping back up, way up, and the rest of my time was spent pressing the B button on the controller to hit rocks.What a ♥♥♥♥ing borefest, 3/10

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Plot (Engaging, but nothing too spectacular):Rusty (if I had a nickel for every robot with that name…) inherits a mineshaft from his dead uncle but soon discovers there’s some pretty weird stuff going on down there. Mainly curiosity is the driving force behind the plot and once that curiosity is fulfilled the rest if somewhat forgettable. On top of that the game ends on a somewhat sad note (and from what I can tell, there aren’t any alternate endings). As for the other characters they’re fairly generic and a bit annoying. You’ve got your old-geezer, rootin-tootin-Texan, rich snob, bimbo and the other fem-bot with a fairly bland personality. One particular quirk that stands out is that Rusty only talks at the beginning and end of the game. In between he’s your silent protagonist. Gameplay (I think I’ve seen similar on a popular flash-game hosting site): If you’re looking for another Terraria you’re going to be disappointed. While it plays borrows from the block-mining genre like Terraria, Starbound and Junk Jack it seems quite lacking in depth by comparison. Mining serves to acquire ores with which to upgrade Rusty. There’s no crafting, all you can do with the ores is sell them for upgrades to buy from the old-geezer, rootin-tootin-Texan and rich-snob. Also you can’t skip upgrades. Say you have enough for the highest tier armor, but you still have basic armor. Before you can buy the highest tier you have to buy the other armors first. Back to the mining, you can’t put blocks back which can make it difficult to reach those ores you missed if you’re not strategic about how you dig. While you can buy ladders you can only hold 5 at a time and you can’t take them back once you set them down. Replay Value (…meh):The game follows a linear path with a definite end rather than a sandbox type game with endless replay value. At the end you’re given an evaluation for your performance such as how long you took or how many times you died. There’s probably an achievement for getting gold on all ranks, but personally I can’t say I find the game interesting enough to try for it. All and all I wouldn’t say it’s a bad game, but if you’re looking for something that will keep you busy long term, look elsewhere.

												Sort of fun, but there are maaaany things it needs. 1. You can't even change half the controls, including movment! The default controls for movement are the arrow keys. They need to change it so you can actually change the controls for moving. 2. IT'S A TOTAL RIP-OFF OF SPELUNKY! Go right now and search "spelunky". Compare the metascores and the fact that it came before this. There you go. 3. I don't like the fact that you have to be facing a certain way if you want to mine that way. I prefer the Terraria style of mining, where you put your mouse over the block you want to mine and click to mine it. Please add this option or something similar. Now, I do understand that this is a very new game, but these are things that should've been fixed before they released it. Especially the most obvious one: BEING ABLE TO CHANGE THE DARN CONTROLS! I don't know how they could've missed that, and I can barely play it because the controls are so awkward! It feels like it was designed for a left-handed person. And as my own personal taste, I would rather play a game like fez or the stanley parable. Go buy those games. They're undeniably fun and enjoyable.

Posted: March 8
												At first glance, SteamWorld Dig may seem like a Terraria-style game, or otherwise a slow-paced game about getting into the dirt.Not so fast there, pardner.This game has a unique aesthetic, a surprisingly interesting story (told without feeling forced or in-your-face), and some very competent platforming controls that let you take on some surprisingly tough sidescrolling challenges. What's more, even the digging itself is interesting; once you dig downwards, you can't easily make a branch off of the shaft you've made, which encourages you to dig careful exploratory shafts to hunt down loot early in the game. There's an element of thoughtfulness to mining in this game, and it works well with the simple combat and platforming.Later in the game, you can expect to face everything from explosives to acid to deadly monsters in the depths, so the game isn't short on diverse challenges, either. Without spoiling anything, suffice to say that by the end of the game, you'll be facing challenges far more bizarre than you probably had in mind. Give the game a try; it'll probably surprise you.

Posted: February 4, 2014
												The notion of ‘digging’ has carved out a niche little sub-genre in recent times. We’ve had the indie juggernaut that is Minecraft, Super tough Spelunky and Terraria to name just a few. SteamWorld Dig  is, as the title suggests, another game that wants you to dig. However, it’s certainly doing it in its own way.Playing as Rusty, a lone steamboat designed for digging, you find yourself exploring a post-apocalyptic world where humans seem to have disappeared. You arrive in the dustbowl town of Tumbleton after receiving the deed to your Uncle Joe’s mine. The town is home to a few remaining robotic inhabitants and it’s up to you to uncover the story of the mine and the towns folk.Your initial forays into the mine will mainly be to find gold and gems which can then be traded and used to upgrade Rusty. All manner of items and upgrades are available and they continually expand as you find more money to spend. Along with this you will gradually uncover more abilities that Rusty can use to help traverse the depths. There’s an element of Metroid to the character advancement but we wouldn’t go as far as to say that this is a Metroidvania.The game world sets itself out into three main sections. You have the town where you can talk and upgrade, the main part of the mine and self-contained rooms within it. For a large amount of the game you’ll be continually digging downward in the main mine area. The goal here is to find cash, avoid critters and find rooms as you uncover the truth of what happened to the humans and the world. The deeper you go, the thicker the rock gets and the tougher the enemies become. Unless you keep upgrading it can be a tiresome task to break through the bedrock so you’ll need to be heading back to the surface to upgrade your pickaxe and other mining gear often.This is perhaps one of the few flaws with the game. While there are a number of short cuts back to the surface, there really aren’t enough of them for it to stop the game from dragging and getting repetitive on occasion. It’s not so bad when going down the mine as you can normally drop down tunnels you’ve dug, but going back up can be tiresome. It’s not enough to take away from the experience in the long term and there are teleporters that can be purchased, but a few more short cuts really wouldn’t have gone a miss.The self-contain rooms within the mine provide a mixture of both platforming and puzzle solving to negotiate. Plot related rooms lead to power ups and boss fights while other hidden areas generally contain precious gems. SteamWorld Dig really is a platformer at heart and these rooms allow for the developers to show off how they have mastered the form. You’ll need quick reflexes and a good understanding of how your powers work to succeed and the difficulty level is pitches just about perfect throughout. Each room and boss is challenging but you’ll always feel you know how you should be beating it - it’s just a case of mustering the skill to do it.There’s something really compelling about the game and as you dig deeper (both literally and into the mystery), you’ll really want to know what’s going on. It’s the sort of game you’ll start playing for a few minutes and end up sticking with for hours. Moving from the 3DS eshop to the PC digital services was always going to be a tough jump but it’s one that SteamWorld Dig has made easily and it shows a skill and understanding by the development team rarely seen elsewhere. SteamWorld Dig may well have gone unnoticed by a lot of you, but we would really recommend checking it out. It’s no longer just one of the best 3DS eshop titles but one of the best digital games available right now and it offers a fun, challenging and fresh experience for gamers to test themselves with no matter the platform.Overall 8/10

Posted: January 23, 2014
												I would just like to start by saying that I absolutely loved this game! It's officially one of my new favorites and I would heartily recommend it to just about anyone.Steamworld Dig is what results in a mashup between something like Terraria, where you're digging a mine through a randomly generated world for resources. And Metroid, where you find upgrades that make your journey easier/more badass. The game's randomly generated "overworld" makes up the bulk of the game, where you're digging your way down looking for minerals that will allow you to purchase upgrades back in town, and looking for the predesigned (not RNG) caves that give you new items or just a little challenge with large rewards. The mineshaft that connects these caves is not as dull as a large pile of underground dirt initially could sound though. The random generation in the world is very well done, making the mine fun to explore as you come across larger open areas, mazelike hard stone that you can't initially dig through, and plenty of enemies. The game also does a very good job teaching you its many mechanisms, with a steady drip of mechanics to keep you interested as you mine your way further down. New enemies, objects that both hurt and help you, and a surprisingly large amount of items for your little digbot to accumulate you'll be seeing new things all the way to the very end. The platforming is also surprisingly well executed, with high flying antics near the end of the game consisting of a super and double jump, dodging a multitude of lasers.Now that I've extolled its virtues, there are a couple of flaws. Nothing major mind, more like missed opportunities that very easily could've come from it being made by a smallish indie developer. First, I feel like the game could've used more of the pre-designed challenges. The challenge caves you find never take very long, and I feel like the game would've been exponentially better if they had gone whole hog on full zeldaesque dungeon design rather than single-multi room platforming challenges. Similarly, I think that having more than a single boss would've helped the difficulty of the game, which, while never easy, isn't one of the hardest I've ever played. It's also a tad shorter than I would've liked, though that's more a personal thing related to wanting to keep playing.Overall, a highly enjoyable game that is most definately worth the very low price of $10.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Dig for ore, sell ore, upgrade equipment. Rinse and repeat. Except with SteamWorld Dig there is enough of a backstory to keep you intrigued and the equipment you are upgrading is....yourself. You are off in search of your father in his old mines and you meet a few interesting characters along the way. Gameplay is as you would expect, audio is about average (which is not to say that it's bad), and the graphics are fairly well done and have a nice polish to them. The game is easy to learn and not too difficult to master.The issue I have with this game is that it's very short. I've almost completely upgraded my character and I've already beaten the game. Once the game is over there isn't much replayability which saddens me because I really do enjoy the feel of the game. The problem with a story arc like the one in this game is that it's not open-ended so you don't feel the need to come back for more when it's over. Hopefully there will be some DLC to help expand the story and give it the replayability that it sorely needs.If you can find it on sale it's a definite grab. If not it depends on what you like in a game. If you enjoy mining/selling/upgrading games then this might be worth the $9 tag.

												SteamWorld Dig possesses a unique combination of old-school progression and mastery, and the modern spelunking style of gameplay. Posted: December 16, 2013
												SteamWorld Dig is very charming and a lot of fun. Many people as whether or not the game is similar to 'Terraria', and the answer is no. If you were to compare SteamWorld Dig to any other game I think the closest would be Motherlode - the old(ish) Flash title that was popular on Miniclip. You go underground, you dig for minerals, you return to the surface to drop them off and make money to purchase new upgrades in order to dig for more minerals, more effectively. It's simple, but the game's constant introduction of new mechanics keep it challenging and interesting. In 2013, where there are so many games out there that focus on exploration that give the player a degree of sandbox freedom, it is fair to wonder whether or not a game like this will gather a large fanbase. In a sandbox game, the exploration and gathering of materials feels a little bit more organic than in Steamworld Dig, where you really only have a few options for upgrades and the resources are essentially melted down into the same currency. SteamWorld has no intention of being that kind of organic exploration/survival title though, but people will still draw that comparison and I am sure that there are people that will find fault with that. If you're looking for a game that fits that description, SteamWorld is not for you.I have two main faults with the game. First, the PC port does not allow for the rebinding of keys. I am usually pretty lax when it comes to crucifying a game for being a lackluster port but not giving me the ability to re-bind keys is a pretty big issue - especially when the game uses up, down, left, right as the movement controls and not WASD, meaning some gamers with 'gaming' keyboards (such as the Logitech G510) will run into input conflicts. I found myself using an Xbox 360 controller and a third party program, which I think benefited the game, but is still inexcusable. Second, the length. I beat Steamworld in 3.5 hours according to my save file, and I am by no means a good gamer. For $9.99, that isn't entirely damning of the game, but it does leave you wanting more. There are plenty of achievements that encourage replay, though.

Posted: December 17, 2013
												This game comes across as Spelunkys more forgiving cousin. You go and dig around and find some precious minerals and gems then hawk them for some cash to buy upgrades for your little robot character.  The art style has steampunk and wild western influence in visual direction and executes it rather well without being too bulk with it. The Music is typical western movie with slight electronic highlights and is quite enjoyable. The game controls quite well with a controller and doesnt feel it'd be unfriendly to a keyboard its easy to pick up and get right into with the layout and movement. When it comes down to it its a fun, simple and short little game worth picking up on sale but dont expect anything particularly groundbreaking despite the interesting turns the adventure takes.

Posted: December 16, 2013
												(7.5/10) SteamWorld Dig is a fun and addictive mining game. You play Rusty, a steambot, who just acquired the will to his uncle's mine. The game has you explore the mine, and as you explore you uncover upgrades, and progress the story. Upgrades are key in this game, and it is exciting to see each new piece of hardware. There is a handful of NPCs in the town of Tumbleton above the mine, and they provide depth of the story, and purchasable upgrades for Rusty. There is a nice list of Steam achievements and a medium replay value. The art style is beautiful, and the audio is surprisingly good. This 2D platformer is a fast paced hour run through, or a leisurely six hour adventure. It is a great PC port from the original Nintendo 3DS.

Posted: February 9, 2014
												SteamWorld Dig is an enjoyable exploration game with bright visuals and fun playability. You control Rusty, a little robot that's come to take over his Uncle's Mine. It starts off innocently enough as you mine for gems to make some money, but the deeper you get, weirder things start showing up. The controls are great; I played with an XBox controller so I can't vouch for keyboard. The gameplay ranges from exploration to a bit of action, to a fair amount of platforming. Throughout the game you buy upgrades that allow you to do a lot more, giving the game a Metroid or Castlevania-esque feel at times. SteamWorld Dig isn't the longest game; there's an achievement for beating it in under two hours. (Though I imagine that's a hard cheevo to get.) My playthrough took five, but I was hellbent on digging up as much gold as I could. It's very enjoyable for what it is, and I could see myself returning to it again for another playthrough.

Posted: March 7, 2014
												This is one of those rare games where back tracking is as enjoyable as the first journey down.  As you get more materials and orbs to upgrade your parts, heading back to previous areas really shows you how far you've come.  Plus, busting through a 5-strength rock in one swing of a pickaxe is so satisfying.  It may not be incredibly long (3.5 hours for a first time while missing a secret area or two), but it's worth the time for a game with simple controls, wonderful aesthetics, and charm coming out of all directions.

Posted: February 4, 2014
												The notion of ‘digging’ has carved out a niche little sub-genre in recent times. We’ve had the indie juggernaut that is Minecraft, Super tough Spelunky and Terraria to name just a few. SteamWorld Dig  is, as the title suggests, another game that wants you to dig. However, it’s certainly doing it in its own way.Playing as Rusty, a lone steamboat designed for digging, you find yourself exploring a post-apocalyptic world where humans seem to have disappeared. You arrive in the dustbowl town of Tumbleton after receiving the deed to your Uncle Joe’s mine. The town is home to a few remaining robotic inhabitants and it’s up to you to uncover the story of the mine and the towns folk.Your initial forays into the mine will mainly be to find gold and gems which can then be traded and used to upgrade Rusty. All manner of items and upgrades are available and they continually expand as you find more money to spend. Along with this you will gradually uncover more abilities that Rusty can use to help traverse the depths. There’s an element of Metroid to the character advancement but we wouldn’t go as far as to say that this is a Metroidvania.The game world sets itself out into three main sections. You have the town where you can talk and upgrade, the main part of the mine and self-contained rooms within it. For a large amount of the game you’ll be continually digging downward in the main mine area. The goal here is to find cash, avoid critters and find rooms as you uncover the truth of what happened to the humans and the world. The deeper you go, the thicker the rock gets and the tougher the enemies become. Unless you keep upgrading it can be a tiresome task to break through the bedrock so you’ll need to be heading back to the surface to upgrade your pickaxe and other mining gear often.This is perhaps one of the few flaws with the game. While there are a number of short cuts back to the surface, there really aren’t enough of them for it to stop the game from dragging and getting repetitive on occasion. It’s not so bad when going down the mine as you can normally drop down tunnels you’ve dug, but going back up can be tiresome. It’s not enough to take away from the experience in the long term and there are teleporters that can be purchased, but a few more short cuts really wouldn’t have gone a miss.The self-contain rooms within the mine provide a mixture of both platforming and puzzle solving to negotiate. Plot related rooms lead to power ups and boss fights while other hidden areas generally contain precious gems. SteamWorld Dig really is a platformer at heart and these rooms allow for the developers to show off how they have mastered the form. You’ll need quick reflexes and a good understanding of how your powers work to succeed and the difficulty level is pitches just about perfect throughout. Each room and boss is challenging but you’ll always feel you know how you should be beating it - it’s just a case of mustering the skill to do it.There’s something really compelling about the game and as you dig deeper (both literally and into the mystery), you’ll really want to know what’s going on. It’s the sort of game you’ll start playing for a few minutes and end up sticking with for hours. Moving from the 3DS eshop to the PC digital services was always going to be a tough jump but it’s one that SteamWorld Dig has made easily and it shows a skill and understanding by the development team rarely seen elsewhere. SteamWorld Dig may well have gone unnoticed by a lot of you, but we would really recommend checking it out. It’s no longer just one of the best 3DS eshop titles but one of the best digital games available right now and it offers a fun, challenging and fresh experience for gamers to test themselves with no matter the platform.Overall 8/10

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Steamworld Dig is a quirky game. It is remenescent of iDigit on the iPhone but with upgrades and some platformer elements (on the set levels). For most of the game you just dig deeper in your grandfather's mine to collect rescources to sell at the town. In the beggining you have little tools and abilities, but within a few minutes you will unlock abilities like dash and super jump. The graphics are remeniscent of the 16-32 bit era but are rendered in HD. The game is simple with only three stats that you need to keep up with: health, Fire and water (the later two being used up as a varation of a mana bar). The game is slightly humorous and keeps the player entertained while also holding the player's hand.

Posted: February 23, 2014
												Everyone who has played Motherload should play this. This game is fun and addictive. You dig (surprise!) your way down the map in search of minerals and caves. You can then sell those minerals to buy better equipment. During your digging you will have to worry about your light supply running out, obstacles and various different enemies.SteamWorld Dig has some minor metroidvania elements. You know the drill (sorry), during the game's progression you get lot's of new equipment and abilities that let you go to different areas, get minerals you previously couldn't or simply make your way down easier.The game has a nice little story behind it, but it's not the focus of it. The graphics and sound are very nice, which adds to the experience.The only thing wrong with this game is it's length. It's too short. The only replay value comes from additional playthroughs to get all the achievements. Or to simply do it again for fun.Despite it's short length, I highly recommend this game. You're gonna dig it. Posted: September 15, 2014
												I played through SteamWorld Dig on my 3DS first, and after about an hour with the PC version I can safely report that it holds up even on a bigger screen and a more powerful machine.It is an enjoyable Metroidvania style game about exploring randomly generated mines in search of new special powers and some sweet minerals. Because of its portable roots the game encourages (or rather forces you into) short mining sessions by giving you a limited amount of lantern time and a very small inventory space for minerals. After you return to the surface you can sell your minerals for some gold, and then buy consumable items or permanent upgrades for your HP or lantern or for the various special powers you come across while mining.The game is in no ways very deep, but it is very easy to get hooked in the simple but rewarding mining. The mixture of scifi/western on the art also makes the game fun and unique. It can also get quite atmospheric on the dimly lit mines which have great ambient background music and changing art assets when you get deeper. SteamWorld Dig comes highly recommended.

												SteamWorld Dig is fantastic dig-sell-upgrade-dig platformer. It is easy to compare it to Terraria because it is 2D and you dig, but there is a lot more to it than that. First, the platforming  feels perfect. Your gem-hungry robot pilots like Super Meat Boy, easily jumping up walls and performing acrobatic maneuvers, making it a blast to navigate the mines. Though it is fairly short and may not have the replayability or depth of the Terarria series, I enjoyed every minute and would highly recommend it to anyone.

I mostly felt that from the crumbling blocks, character upgrades, and mini map. Top all that off with great loveable characters (regardless of their annoying voices), compelling (and shockingly) post apocalyptic setting, and awesome main character. This is one game that you'll feel sad to complete, because it was so good and endearing that you want more. Luckily, this game has immense replay value, so if you can't get enough give it another go!Highly reccomended for fans of Minecraft, Terraria, and all "Metroidvania" style games! Now go mine that ore for yourself, get this game!

Posted: April 30, 2014
SteamWorld Dig is probably my favorite game of 2013. It's an incredible little side-scrolling platformer title with strong Metroidvanian influences about a robot who digs up valuables in an attempt to reinvigorate a desert town. You take control of Rusty as you mine rare minerals, take on enemies, and uncover ancient treasures deep below the surface.If you can believe it from the screenshots, SteamWorld Dig actually began as a Nintendo 3DS eShop game! They have completely revamped the game for PC by adding HD visuals (including high-resolution textures, animated character portraits, bloom filter, and more!), gamepad support, achievements, trading cards, and some rather tongue-in-cheek jokes exclusively for the PC crowd.The game runs consistently at 60 FPS and just looks beautiful overall. Rusty and his enemies are smoothly animated and the surrounding backgrounds and textures are sharp and lend a great sense of atmosphere to the game. Everything in SteamWorld Dig has a really nice, hand-drawn look that really stands out. This is a game that I highly suggest you enjoy on your television while sitting back on the couch.The gameplay is pretty straight forward, but incredibly fun. When you begin the main story, you're given a pickax, a solid layer or dirt, and a simple objective: DIG. In SteamWorld Dig, you carve your own route through the levels. There are 4 main areas, each of them bigger than the last and sporting unique themes), that are completely destructible.Along the way, you'll discover rare minerals that you can sell topside to the local vendor to upgrade and expand your arsenal of digging utensils. Deep underground, there's also secret areas that have fun puzzles that reward you with more minerals or special upgrades upon completion.I won't sugar coat this last bit: The game is short. It only took me roughly 4 or 5 hours to complete. It's pretty obvious that it was made for fairly brief play sessions on a mobile platform such as the 3DS.HOWEVER, it packs so much content into those 5 hours. You're constantly discovering, puzzling, jumping, dashing, falling, climbing, upgrading, teleporting, and most importantly DIGGING. I can't stress enough how ridiculously charming and fun this game is. In my opinion, it is entirely worth the base price of $9.99.http://forums.fungineers.net/index.php?topic=1408.msg22679#msg22679

Posted: September 16, 2014
												I like the fact how simple this game is, you can grasp all the main concepts in a few minutes. Still, even though being that simple, it is very much enjoyable. Especially for us, collectors and perfectionists, it's very charming to be able to dig through the world and try to find every single last precious ore nugget that is out there.The game length is 6 - 10 hours, and that's a benefit for me. The worlds were quite different and they introduced new concepts, which is great, one would never feel bored.The only thing I disliked about this game is the "light" game concept. It seems to be that it was introduced in order to make the game less plain, to make the game mechanics more complex. Which I agree with, it would be way too simple otherwise. But it's not designed properly. With current design, you simply have to go above ground every few minutes, even though your bag is almost empty and you have no other reason to return, just to refill the light lamp. That often means spending up to several minutes traversing the mine to the top. That's crazy, and it's annoying as hell. Some possible improvements to this concept include: a) an ability to refill the oil from the (eternal) lamps scattered through the level, maybe at the expense of extinguishing that lamp forever b) an ability to purchase and take with you an extra flask of oil, maybe even at the expense of one of the inventory slots. With this approach, you have immediately made the game less painful and also more interesting, because there is very interesting choice to be had - spend more money and have less inventory space, but have longer and more convenient light? Those are exactly the right tough question every game should offer. Sadly, in this case, it was not though out well.Except for the single issue mentioned above, I very much enjoyed how the game looked and played, and recommend it to everyone enjoying this kind of casual exploring/digging/a bit puzzle and platforming genre.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												It's a modern graphics version of the old Dig Dug or Motherload games. As usual, dig down, go back up, buy upgrades to dig further down and move around better. The bottom layer is usually a hell layer with the big boss, which is usually your mentor or father or some other kind of person gone bad.It doesn't add anything new other than graphics and a cool soundtrack and a cool western robot setting. If you've seen Futurama, Bender, those types of robots.Remember that it is a mobile game ported to PC so it is very short.My total hours probably say something around 4 hours... that's how long it takes to beat.You don't actually do all that much mining. You just dig down, make sure to get a few ores on the way and that's it. It has a slight puzzle aspect to it because you can't mine diagonally, you can't mine while hanging from a ceiling etc. You can only mine up 1 block, left, right and down. So if you don't play smart, you can get stuck. Upgrades aleviate this but not entirely.I got it in a bundle, so paid maybe 1 buck for it. The graphics and themes and sounds are more polished than other games in its genre so I'd say it's worth a few bucks.There's many flash games out there for free, with the same gameplay.

Posted: September 13, 2014
												A delightful little surprise this one.It's a very cool metroidvania-lite blockbased digging platformer. Unlike games like Minecraft or Terraria you can't place new blocks, so you actually have to be careful when digging so you don't get stuck. You also have to be careful not to make it impossible to dig areas above you, because you can't swing during a jump, so you need to stand on the ground to dig, so if you dug too far down to reach something above you, you have to go back up again and dig down on a different place.It's a game where you can't just dig mindlessly, especially not as falling un-diggable blocks begins flooding your mine, if they land on minerals or ore-blocks they might very well crush the ore, losing you money. They can also trap you if you're not careful, and if you're unaware you might even get one falling right down on your head, costing you your life and 50% of the money you have on you.As you dig deeper and deeper you unlock more things that solve frustrating situations you previously couldn't deal with, and allow you to dig more carelessly, but at the same time that carefreeness can easily become your undoing.It's a very fun game that ate up several hours of my time completely unexpectedly. You can beat it in probably 3 1/2 - 4 hours, but if you're like me and try to make all the fallable blocks fall as far as the level allows them, then you will phase into a world of deep concentration in what I would like to call Tetris Hell.Expect to die.

Posted: July 6, 2015
												SteamWorld Dig is quite amazing, really.The game gives you a pickaxe, and you dig. You get cool ores, you sell them, then you get better gear so you can dig more. Then you dig, and there's digging.But there's so much more than that, too. The game has a great learning curve that ramps up difficulty to a challenging, rewarding, and satisfying gameplay experience. I got this in the sale (why not?) and was awed by its intuitive design. Whether you're figuring out how to get that awkwardly-placed mineral or your outburst of mining TNT has led to a chain reaction explosion, the game will find a way to make the simple prospect (excuse the pun) of mining enjoyable in an unexpected way.This isn't Minecraft. It's not Terraria. It's a completely different gaming experience that will turn you from an amateur digger to a platforming pro.Oh, but there is ONE small problem. The controls are awkward (arrow keys to move and wasd to use tools), something cringeworthy for any seasoned PC gamer, but it was designed with a 3DS in mind, so you can't blame the developers...9/10:Worth your money. 100% awesome.

Posted: July 7, 2015
												Steamworld Dig is a fairly predictable and simple action/platformer. Most of your time is spent digging to get ores to sell in order to improve your ability to dig. Or rather, since the ground gets more dense as you dig deeper, to maintain your ability to dig at a given rate. Your tools also double as weapons, though none of the enemies are particularly difficult or interesting. All of the upgrades you can buy are simple stat increases, and the new tech you discover is unoriginal and predictable.But it isn't a bad game. The world is interesting and hints at a backstory that may be more interesting than the game's Mcguffin plot. SD has a sharp aesthetic, good music, smooth animations, and well-executed, if unoriginal gameplay. If Metroid meets Minecraft sounds good to you, you can get an enjoyable 2.5 - 8 hours here, depending on how much you search for ore.

Posted: September 27, 2014
												This is a fun little platformer type game. Due to upgrades you get, you could say it is a metroidvania type game.You start out with nothing and are dropped into the underground caves of a town. You a local, and are told about you uncle. Shortly after, you get you first item, a pick axe.The game revolves around using digging devices (throughout the game you find more) to keep mining the gems under the town and fend off enimies. While there are enimies, that isn't the highlight of the game. You keep getting upgrades of your digging devices as well throughout the game.If you die, you drop all the gems you are carring and are returned to town. Posted: July 6, 2014
												Steamworld dig is accourding to most people the next "Must-have" Game on the 3ds and Steam but is it really true well let's begin with the story of the game.WARNING: Spoiler alert!The story is about a robot named Rusty coming to a town named Tumbleton when he falls into his uncle's mine. When he falls into the mine he runs into dorothy which after a brief conversation he goes to find his father when he finds out that his uncle died in the mine so you "borrow" his pickaxe to find out what he was up to. Then after a while he falls into the second section of the mine known as Old world a nuclear plant section. Then later you reach vectron a electronic generator underground where after mining a bit ou reach the final boss of the game known as the Voltbot who plans on taking over the world making voltbots the dominant species on the planet. After destroying the voltbot the mine collapses on you and you end up dying in the mine. Then the townspeople build a statue of Rusty and then the credits roll...ok I know what your thinking why didn't I mention the townspeople well because all they really do in the game is give you upgrades to your tools.The Gameplay:The gameplay is a mix of Metroid and Minecraft. But what do you do in steamworld dig you mine then sell your ore then go back to the mine then sell and so on. It doesn't sound like much but it's a really addicting game. Like Minecraft the main goal is to well Mine. Like Metroid the game is setup like a maze except you make the path But when you leave the cave it doesn't reset so you need to think out a move before you do it. But there is one major flaw it ends too soon just when your used to everything the game ends with the only boss in the game the voltbot also it takes around 5-6 hours to beat give or take. Yet this is also the best thing in the game too because when you beat the game it posts your score so it makes you destined to come back to beat your last score. Also there's another flaw  which are the side characters they just don't do anything but upgrade your tools. The Verdict:Steamworld dig is one of those masterpieces that comes around every once in a while where a game is so good you always remember the experience you had playing the game. This game is a must have game in anyone's steam library. The game is $9.99 and that is a great price so this game gets a 9.5 out of 10.Pros:+ Great story+ Addictive Gameplay+ Amazing replay value+ Great visuals and soundtrackCons:- Side characters- Length 9.5Must-Have

Posted: August 1, 2015
												StoryDig to find 'Joe'... and everything else the NPCs say is just a runaround way of saying this.Adds some depth to the character and background plot but nothing really changes. I found myself skipping dialogue. Visuals+ Rich colour and vibrant artsyle paired with fluid animation makes each area unique.- Although the lighting is great for 2D sprites, as a mechanic to manage feels a bit annoying.Audio+ Cool Westerny title music, Very effective SFX audio in the character voices and every action.- The rest of the game's music is atmospheric I guess as caves are but is not very memorable.Gameplay+ The movement felt weighty and awkward at first but it just made it feel more like you were a robot.+ Most of the mechanics feel really great but it takes quite a while to obtain them to feel fun.- Although the gameplay prides itself a "Strong Metroidvanian" Influence.. it is not. Those games have a sense exploration... this one you just keep heading down.- The game is quite easy and most of the 'challenge' is managing your inventory. Replenishing light, save points, water, and emptying your treasure bag are not fun... it just slows things down and feels more like a chore.- Puzzles are not hard. Enemies types are quite limted. Environmental hazards pose more a threat than enemeies.- There is only one boss.Overall: 5/10 (Meh)The game is quite short and not challenging, however what it does, it does well.As soon as you obtain all the abilities... the game is over. There's no real motivation for replay value except to acquire half of the achievements. The ending was also quite 'dry' and will leave you wanting more.

Posted: August 1, 2015
												Another styish indie title I picked up at a bargain price, I hear SteamWorld Dig compared often to Spelunky, though I have not played that title. What I can tell you is that it is a 2D digging game that casts you as rugged frontier steambot Rusty, who travels out to the tiny town of Tumbleton one day to speak with his uncle, who he soon finds has passed on. But Rusty's uncle left behind a series of clues that will lead him to the deepests depths of the world, and to a terrible secret. You begin the game with a simple pickaxe that can only dig horizontally or vertically. Make sure not to dig under any rocks and crush yourself! Along the way the player digs up ore that can be traded for money back in town, and in turn used to buy useful upgrades and items such as ladders and dynamite. Skirting into the realm of Metroidvania, Rusty can come across strange, blue platforms that grant him incredible new abilities, such as double jumping. Though Rusty can dig almost anywhere in the main cavern, there are side caverns where he must follow a set path as if in a dungeon, various enemies and puzzles barring his way. There's decent music too, most notably the main theme, a take on Ennio Morricone's "The Ecstasy of Gold." Steamworld Dig will hand you the occasional cheap death, and you may not immediately realize that there is a finite amount of ore in a single playthrough, and therefore limited cash, so spend it wisely and avoid taking any uncesssary risks. Steamworld Dig took me a fair bit of time to get through, though I took the time to dig up every last piece of ore I could find to ensure I'd have the cash I needed. This game will reward the cautious and meticulous player, as it did me. It's a lovely title overall and I would play it again.

												I'll say that I like robots and that I like the wild west. It has both so I can't complain. Steamworld Dig is a great mining game with several influences such as Terarria, Megaman and Metroid. You play as Rusty who has inherited an old mine from his uncle. The main objective is to mine, collect ores, sell them and reach for the bottem of the mine. It was originally released on 3DS and the game is quite appealing to the eye, they managed to add quite a bit of colour for a mining game which is nice. The music is decent but I wouldn't say catchy. It more melds right into the game which is great as it adds to the game. The mining in the game is all about risk versus reward and it is done quite superbly.Overall I give it 8.5/10 Its fun, looks great and you can play the game in your own pace. If you're not a big fan of games like Minecraft or Terraria, you should at least give this a go because (for people like me) it has a story and an ending plus the game has a bit to offer.

Posted: May 11, 2015
												Clearly inspired by Motherload, SteamWorld Dig is a satisfying and addictive "snack" game. It's easy to sit down and play for just a few minutes, but much like a bag of chips you can sit down intending to eat just a handful and accidentally eat the whole bag.Though the game mostly consists of mining downwards and gathering ores to sell in order to purchase upgrades, there are puzzle/platforming elements throughout. It helps keep things fresh and interesting.It is worth noting that the story- though quite subtle and not of utmost importance- is actually quite interesting. Image and Form has done an admirable job on building an unusual universe. It's enough to keep me hooked for their next project, SteamWorld Heist.Time to completion will range from 4-6 hours on average mostly depending on how thorough you are in your ore collection. I have now purchased two separate bundles containing this game and gave the second code to a friend of mine. Now he's addicted too. $11 CAD is a reasonable price for this game, but if you don't want to spend that, grab it when it's on sale. You won't regret it.

Posted: September 27, 2014
												This is a fun little platformer type game. Due to upgrades you get, you could say it is a metroidvania type game.You start out with nothing and are dropped into the underground caves of a town. You a local, and are told about you uncle. Shortly after, you get you first item, a pick axe.The game revolves around using digging devices (throughout the game you find more) to keep mining the gems under the town and fend off enimies. While there are enimies, that isn't the highlight of the game. You keep getting upgrades of your digging devices as well throughout the game.If you die, you drop all the gems you are carring and are returned to town. You loose 50% of your gold as well, so you want to avoid this. The first time through you might find yourself digging down faster than you should. It is wise to plan ahead so you can always get back up to sell those precious gems.While at first there might not be much stratigy, as stated above you do need to be careful just digging down and fast. Plan ahead, so you have tunnels that you can use to your advantage. Thera are consumable's you can use to help out, but I found them not very useful. I found spending my money on upgrades more worth the money.There are 3 diffrent "types" of mning areas you go through. They get progresivly harder to mine, but the game overall isn't very challanging.Overall I would recomend the game. I also feel it is sutable for the younger crowd if you are looking for your children. I played the game completly with a wireless xbox 360 controler, and had no issues with it. I do now know how a KBAM would be.

Posted: February 16, 2016
												Ok so full disclosure I haven't played this game fully on steam but have recently purchased on xbox and racked up about 15 hours on xbox which should go to show you how great this game. Overall your playing as a robot with other robots trying to revive a town and find what your uncle was working on. Overall the story gets lost really. All you need to know is that you dig and along the way you pick up some sci fi powerups your uncle found and try to figure what is buried down there. In reality if you got the mineral radar before hand this game would be signifigantly shorter as there are only 3 worlds and is my one big complaint about this game because it is so fun I wanted to keep on playing but seeing as this developer only has one game I hope the capital they gain from this game will allow them to make longer games in the future. Overall the mining is where it is at as you can dig side to sidse or down but you gotta be careful because you can't dig upwards easily or at all in some places if you screw up and you can't get the exact angle. You carry a latern which goes by 60 second intervals so you gotta refill it by going to the surface and you can only carry so many minerals. Refilling your minerals will give you money to buy upgrades and passing certain thresholds allows more people to come to town and purchase better upgrade.  Again this game would be a lot shorter and I think the developer realized the mineral radar at the very end. You are given a mini map but your not able to view the whole thing only what your currently right by which can be annoying but it does shows you entrances to places. Honestly for a first game this is very good and definitly worth your purchase. What I hope to see the developer do is expand on this for a possible sequel. Its much like the first portal its very short and leaves you wanting more.  My only other word of caution to the developer is that because minerals don't respawn the only way to heal yourself is money or by farming enemies which can be tedious and dying doesn't refill your health fully. Granted they give you a wide burth but still.  I would pick this up on sale its well worth it

YouTube™ Video: Review-O-Lution - Episode #1: SteamWorld Dig 

			Views: 17		

			This is the pilot episode to the my new review show, Review-O-Lution (Re-view-O-Lu-Tion). Today we review a game on Steam, called SteamWorld Dig an indie platformer and mining game that I will tell...		

I do recommend first of all to anyone who may play this game, but I do suggest buying this game on a sale day, because one of the few problems I found with the game is that it is short for its pricing. BUT I enjoyed the mechanics of platforming in a 2D enviroment but with the possiblity of destroying the grounds around you. It has some humor that I find quite charming, and some of the jokes are obvious but I smiled when some of them happen. NOW there are some issues I did have such as some characters not being as well... memorable or as lasting to me, so I didn't feel to attached to them. But some were pretty funny and nice to talk to but there weren't that many good moments that allowed me to get to know them better. Maybe if the Saloon in town was a place you could hang out with all of them maybe that could have maybe them more memorable. But overall I do suggest playing this at some point it is very great in my opinion, I just think you should get it cheaper.

Posted: April 28, 2015
												Combine Terraria + Spelunky and strip them of all their fun, and that's the end result.I'm sincerely baffled by all the positive reviews this game has... It almost feels like people didn't even test the game at all.Don't let yourself fooled like I did, it's really not worth your time at all.If you want a fun Metroidvania, just play Unepic.If you want a fun rogue-like, play Spelunky.If you want a fun mining game, play Terraria (or even Minecraft)I gave this game a chance and finished it with (almost) all achievements, but I'm not gonna recommend it to anyone, so many things are just plain bad about the game.It's boring repetitive, and the controls are not even nearly as tight as a Super Meat Boy, especially the wall-jumping, oh God the wall-jumping, did they even finish coding their game?Thumbs up for the graphics though, I gotta admit the 2D steampunk atmosphere is very appealing visually.+ Visuals- Way too short (~4 hours for all upgrades)- Too repetitive, you'll notice that after your first 10 minutes (no joke)- Music is sincerely dull and bland- Controls are approximative at best, but the wall-jumping timing mechanics get the cakeFinal note: 3/10

Posted: December 1, 2014
												Steamworld Dig is a fun and immersive game that follows the story of a lone steambot called Rusty. He came to a town called Tumbleton because his uncle sent him the claim to his mine. After finding out that your uncle has passed away you get thrown right into the game.The core gameplay of Steamworld Dig is to mine valuable ore and bring it back up to the surface for money. With this money you can then buy all sorts of upgrades that will help you explore even deeper into your uncle's mine and find more valuable ore. Even though it may seem that all you do is digging, there is actually a really cool story that unfolds as the game progresses.The game also allows for different styles of gameplay. You can try to go through the game as fast as you can, or you can take your time and try to collect every single piece of loot you can find.While playing the game I have also found a few bugs. However, they are really minor so I'm not going to nitpick about them.All in all, Steamworld Dig is a really fun game and I would recommend it to anyone. So if you're on the fence about this game, definitely pick it up.

Posted: January 17, 2015
												It is apparently a Metroid-influenced game, but I haven't played Metroid. It is also quite like Terraria due to the mining down and collecting precious stones. In SteamWorld Dig there is considerably less emphasis on open-world exploring and extreme numbers of items to collect, and more of an obvious storyline.I found the game good fun. Unlike the beginning of Terraria, it was obvious what to do, and I was clear on my next goal. Roll into town with population 3, talk with the NPCs, then down the mine and start hacking away. The NPCs have exaggerated personalities, which is to be expected I suppose, and are rather obvious and traditional in their roles. It would have been nice to mix things up a bit. As I dig further down, I found quickly that it pays to go horizontally more than vertically, and any vertical movement needs to be carefully planned. Even with the higher jump and other power-ups collected later on, it can still be very difficult to go back up without a little forethought. Rusty can only dig one space up, and cannot dig while jumping.I was pleased that the pause screen displayed the current keys to use - this made it easy to quickly check how to change objects to place, rather than accidentally placing an object. The inventory is straightforward and provides all the information required while playing. It is possible to further inspect the inventory and reject items, but I haven't needed to do that. The movement and hit zones for Rusty are reasonable. I was frustrated occasionally by digging the wrong space, just because I was slightly off centre over the top of rocks. The map is very useful in seeing where I'd been, and what's coming up. Displaying the number of strikes required to mine the default rocks as separate levels was very helpful. I would have liked a way to see the current goal again - new goals pop up in a red banner once the previous goal is achieved, but I haven't found a way to see the goal again.Overall a pleasant game, simpler and more straightforward than Terraria, but with reasonable progression and some small choices to be made between available upgrades. I would recommend this game as a casual game, as a small amount of time invested can give a good return. For more complex or open-ended exploration and building, Terraria is the way to go. SteamWorld Dig is a fun way to pass some time.

Posted: October 7, 2014
												A post-apocalyptic tale (with Old West influences) of a robot who goes into a mine to continue the work of his robot uncle. You dig down, look for minerals, and unravel the mystery of how your relative disappeared. This is a simple side-scrolling platformer with some RPG elements, but a worthwhile one. It's paced nicely, the gameplay is good, the art and characters are interesting, etc. To beat the game it requires about 3-9 hours of playtime depending on how much you explore and how many upgrades you want (personally I don't mind grinding but others may disagree). SteamWorld Dig is a bit lighthearted and casual, but it's not a yawnsome breeze to play either. You'll probably encounter a few parts here and there that are semi-challenging. Nothing serious of course, but it was nice to see some level of strategy beyond "point and click anywhere to win."I'm not sure if the game is worth $10 - maybe a bit closer to $5 - but it's well done. 8/10, like Metacritic says, seems accurate. Not the best game ever, but it's pretty fun and worth a try. I got this in a Humble Bundle and it's definitely worth more than what I paid.

Posted: February 1, 2015
												SteamWorld Dig is the kind of game that targets a specific gameplay loop with its design, and it reaches it while not really bothering with anything else. It's pure Metroidvania fundamentals, straight out of the book of Metroidvania fundamentals. You will most likely enjoy this game if you liked the Metroids, Castlevanias, Akuji the Demon, Cave Story, Strider (2014) or Dust: An Elysian Tail. It essentially plays the same way, but with a bit of Minecraft mixed in as well. However, the actual end product has a Feel and Mood more reminiscent of a 2D-Platformer-Steampunk-Harvest-Moon. Your Money and your XP are one and the same. You don't downlevel when you spend it, don't worry - so be going for every upgrade. It'll help you a lot too. SteamWorld Dig is a short game, but it has great visuals, great atmosphere and a cozy sense of adventuring underground. If you enjoy this kind of game, with a lot of mining for resources and upgrading, and progressing downwards, you will REALLY enjoy THIS game in particular. The controls and movements feel chunky and satisfying, and returning down into the mine, then going back up to Town with a Portal feels almost like Diablo or FATE. This is not a long game - but it is a good game. I'd rather play a well-designed game that's short, than a poorly designed game that's long, that I'll never beat.The mines themselves (but not the Instanced Dungeons within them) are randomized every playthrough. Enjoy.

Posted: September 17, 2014
												Metroid and Dig Dug had a baby!Fun and satisfying.7.5 / 10Cons:- Once you dig fairly deep into one of the mine locations, it becomes a chore to climb back out to save and re-supply.- The game has only one boss at the very end of the 3rd Mine location. It would have been nice to have at least one for each location.Pros:- The game is a platformer and puzzle solver. Just exploring the mines and digging for valuables is a puzzle in technique so that you don't get stuck, miss something, or make it hard to access something later. You have to think each time you swing your pick.- Metroid style upgrades that give your character powerful and fun new abilities keep the game exciting, while upgrades to your new equipment can be purchased by mining for valuables, making it less of a grind.Tips:- Death isn't that bad... Unless you're hording cash. Dying takes away 50% of your cash for repairs! It does NOT take your minerals or orbs (though your minerals will be dropped where you die and you will have to go back to get them). So make sure that when you cash in your ore for money, SPEND AS MUCH OF IT AS POSSIBLE IMMEDIATELY. This way, if you die, you'll lose some pocket change and not a paycheck, and there is only so much money to be gained in the game.- Don't buy teleporters. They cost orbs, which are rare and even more limited than ore. There will be more short-cuts and teleporters to the surface the deeper you go, so be patient and save those orbs for upgrades.

Posted: September 18, 2014
												Mindless fun. Not very challenging, but scratched an itch. In short you go into a mine, dig up gems, avoid or attack monsters, return to the surface, sell gems, buy upgrades, and dig deeper into the mine. Repeat. There are little puzzle sections to progress to the next section of the mine that are probably my favorite part of the game, mainly because it's pretty much the only part of the game you really need to think a little. That said, there are some interesting hazards throughout the different levels of the mines that make you think about where you're digging. You also quickly learn to not just dig willy-nilly so that you don't accidentally make some gems impossible to reach. Art style was cute, story was practically non-existent, and sound design was good. Not an incredible game by any stretch, but well worth it as part of the Humble Bundle.

Posted: September 15, 2014
												I played through SteamWorld Dig on my 3DS first, and after about an hour with the PC version I can safely report that it holds up even on a bigger screen and a more powerful machine.It is an enjoyable Metroidvania style game about exploring randomly generated mines in search of new special powers and some sweet minerals. Because of its portable roots the game encourages (or rather forces you into) short mining sessions by giving you a limited amount of lantern time and a very small inventory space for minerals. After you return to the surface you can sell your minerals for some gold, and then buy consumable items or permanent upgrades for your HP or lantern or for the various special powers you come across while mining.The game is in no ways very deep, but it is very easy to get hooked in the simple but rewarding mining. The mixture of scifi/western on the art also makes the game fun and unique. It can also get quite atmospheric on the dimly lit mines which have great ambient background music and changing art assets when you get deeper. SteamWorld Dig comes highly recommended.

Posted: September 19, 2014
												This game surprised me. I bought a HumbleBundle and SteamWorld Dig was part of it. I don't like the steampunk genre, from the screenshots I didn't like the game color tones like warm/desert stuff and the gameplay seemed, well, like a rehash of other games.I still registered the game to my account even though I was about to gift it. Then I tried it real quick expecting a shït little game.How wrong was I.This game is actually very good. It's very addictive thanks to a progression mechanic: you dig, find ore, sell them, and after a certain amount of ore has been sold, the town's people can create upgrades for you using them. Obviously you will have better pickaxes but not just that. You can buy teleport beacons thingy to go back in the main cave in no time for example.Sometime while digging, you will encounter small caves. Entering them will present you a puzzle like environment where you need to reach a specific area. Some caves are part of the game story, and completing them will grant you new abilities, like double jump or using your fist and stuff.Using those new skills you'll be able to reach ore inaccessible before. You see, our dude can only dig one tile around him. Some ore are sometimes across a pit or something. You'll be like "damn that's too far." So you'll keep digging and upgrade more and more. It is very rewarding.The story of the game is... well average. The graphics, the drawings are nice. Animation is good too. Nothing else to report.The difficulty is awesome. It's progressive but never too hard or too easy. Very nice.Finally the game controls are just very good. I played this using a DS4 pad and DS4Windows. All the movements are smooth and I had no trouble moving my dude around. I changed however the dig button to right trigger so I could hold that stuff down for long time.The only 'problem' with the game is its replayability: levels are not randomly generated :/I have seen reviews saying it’s a good thing because the game focuses on speed running, which I hate. But tru dat we have leaderboards and achievements like finish the game in less than two hours and stuff. I guess the whole game becomes a real crazy puzzle if you wanna speed run. Yep I can't even imagine that. BDSM style :DWell I recommend the game, it is well made, has lots of details, never crashed, and is... just good you know. 10 hours of that game were required to finish it, after having explored everything and taking care of looking stuff around. Definitely worth it.

Posted: May 6, 2014
Click Here for the Full Review! [monthsbehindreviews.blogspot.com]Synopsis: An interesting blend of DigDug and Metroid, where you drill and pickaxe your way through strata, grabbing ores and gems as you go, making your way from cave to cave in search of upgrades and the reason why your deceased uncle left you a mining claim in a town with a population of 3. Back topside you can sell your goods for cash, which you can use to buy additional incremental upgrades for the major ones you've found in your travels.It's a fun little game, though it does have it's quirks. Some of the navigating can be tricky, such as wall jumping, and you can't dig upwards at a diagonal, so be careful you don't get stuck, because having to self destruct (or any other death) means losing half your cash and dropping all your loot (this last bit can be recovered). Worth your time, which won't be much because the speed achievement requires you to beat it in around 2 hours (it took my 7, but I grabbed all the loot, and died more than a few times from digging under a rock). I'd suggest getting it around $2.50, and enjoying a sadly brief respite from Real Life (c) problems. I give it an 8/10.

												Charming, little game with a lot of heart. It’s not as difficult as Spelunky, nor is it as open as Terreria. What it is is a simple, well crafted and responsive controlled game. Posted: January 23, 2014
												I would just like to start by saying that I absolutely loved this game! It's officially one of my new favorites and I would heartily recommend it to just about anyone.Steamworld Dig is what results in a mashup between something like Terraria, where you're digging a mine through a randomly generated world for resources. And Metroid, where you find upgrades that make your journey easier/more badass. The game's randomly generated "overworld" makes up the bulk of the game, where you're digging your way down looking for minerals that will allow you to purchase upgrades back in town, and looking for the predesigned (not RNG) caves that give you new items or just a little challenge with large rewards. The mineshaft that connects these caves is not as dull as a large pile of underground dirt initially could sound though. The random generation in the world is very well done, making the mine fun to explore as you come across larger open areas, mazelike hard stone that you can't initially dig through, and plenty of enemies. The game also does a very good job teaching you its many mechanisms, with a steady drip of mechanics to keep you interested as you mine your way further down. New enemies, objects that both hurt and help you, and a surprisingly large amount of items for your little digbot to accumulate you'll be seeing new things all the way to the very end. The platforming is also surprisingly well executed, with high flying antics near the end of the game consisting of a super and double jump, dodging a multitude of lasers.Now that I've extolled its virtues, there are a couple of flaws. Nothing major mind, more like missed opportunities that very easily could've come from it being made by a smallish indie developer. First, I feel like the game could've used more of the pre-designed challenges. The challenge caves you find never take very long, and I feel like the game would've been exponentially better if they had gone whole hog on full zeldaesque dungeon design rather than single-multi room platforming challenges. Similarly, I think that having more than a single boss would've helped the difficulty of the game, which, while never easy, isn't one of the hardest I've ever played. It's also a tad shorter than I would've liked, though that's more a personal thing related to wanting to keep playing.Overall, a highly enjoyable game that is most definately worth the very low price of $10.

Posted: February 1, 2015
												SteamWorld Dig is the kind of game that targets a specific gameplay loop with its design, and it reaches it while not really bothering with anything else. It's pure Metroidvania fundamentals, straight out of the book of Metroidvania fundamentals. You will most likely enjoy this game if you liked the Metroids, Castlevanias, Akuji the Demon, Cave Story, Strider (2014) or Dust: An Elysian Tail. It essentially plays the same way, but with a bit of Minecraft mixed in as well. However, the actual end product has a Feel and Mood more reminiscent of a 2D-Platformer-Steampunk-Harvest-Moon. Your Money and your XP are one and the same. You don't downlevel when you spend it, don't worry - so be going for every upgrade. It'll help you a lot too. SteamWorld Dig is a short game, but it has great visuals, great atmosphere and a cozy sense of adventuring underground. If you enjoy this kind of game, with a lot of mining for resources and upgrading, and progressing downwards, you will REALLY enjoy THIS game in particular. The controls and movements feel chunky and satisfying, and returning down into the mine, then going back up to Town with a Portal feels almost like Diablo or FATE. This is not a long game - but it is a good game. I'd rather play a well-designed game that's short, than a poorly designed game that's long, that I'll never beat.The mines themselves (but not the Instanced Dungeons within them) are randomized every playthrough. Enjoy.

Posted: December 16, 2013
												SteamWorld Dig is very charming and a lot of fun. Many people as whether or not the game is similar to 'Terraria', and the answer is no. If you were to compare SteamWorld Dig to any other game I think the closest would be Motherlode - the old(ish) Flash title that was popular on Miniclip. You go underground, you dig for minerals, you return to the surface to drop them off and make money to purchase new upgrades in order to dig for more minerals, more effectively. It's simple, but the game's constant introduction of new mechanics keep it challenging and interesting. In 2013, where there are so many games out there that focus on exploration that give the player a degree of sandbox freedom, it is fair to wonder whether or not a game like this will gather a large fanbase. In a sandbox game, the exploration and gathering of materials feels a little bit more organic than in Steamworld Dig, where you really only have a few options for upgrades and the resources are essentially melted down into the same currency. SteamWorld has no intention of being that kind of organic exploration/survival title though, but people will still draw that comparison and I am sure that there are people that will find fault with that. If you're looking for a game that fits that description, SteamWorld is not for you.I have two main faults with the game. First, the PC port does not allow for the rebinding of keys. I am usually pretty lax when it comes to crucifying a game for being a lackluster port but not giving me the ability to re-bind keys is a pretty big issue - especially when the game uses up, down, left, right as the movement controls and not WASD, meaning some gamers with 'gaming' keyboards (such as the Logitech G510) will run into input conflicts. I found myself using an Xbox 360 controller and a third party program, which I think benefited the game, but is still inexcusable. Second, the length. I beat Steamworld in 3.5 hours according to my save file, and I am by no means a good gamer. For $9.99, that isn't entirely damning of the game, but it does leave you wanting more. There are plenty of achievements that encourage replay, though.

												This game comes across as Spelunkys more forgiving cousin. Posted: December 18, 2013
												I think IGN pretty much nailed it when they likened this game to a cross between the arcade classic DigDug and old-school console platformer/adventure favorites like Metroid. Overall, it's a nice, breezy title...but it SCREAMS for why Steam so desperately needs a SteamBox Console/Big-Screen version with decent controller support, as it's a crime to try and play this game with a keyboard and mouse and even using and Xbox console controller on a PC screen just feels like it's not doing the game justice.  I feel like I should be jamming a cartridge into a gray plastic machine, untangling controller wires, and waiting for my CRT to warm up before playing this title...cursing when the game won't boot a few times, blowing dust off the contacts of the cartridge and re-trying again and again (even though I know that won't help)...and playing this the "right" way.  ...and that's not a bad thing at all.  Kudos to the devs on a fun title.  Too bad I just wasn't one of the lucky 0.075% of applicants who actually got to beta the SteamBox hardware.  I mean...what's a guy gotta do?

Posted: July 6, 2014
												Steamworld dig is accourding to most people the next "Must-have" Game on the 3ds and Steam but is it really true well let's begin with the story of the game.WARNING: Spoiler alert!The story is about a robot named Rusty coming to a town named Tumbleton when he falls into his uncle's mine. When he falls into the mine he runs into dorothy which after a brief conversation he goes to find his father when he finds out that his uncle died in the mine so you "borrow" his pickaxe to find out what he was up to. Then after a while he falls into the second section of the mine known as Old world a nuclear plant section. Then later you reach vectron a electronic generator underground where after mining a bit ou reach the final boss of the game known as the Voltbot who plans on taking over the world making voltbots the dominant species on the planet. After destroying the voltbot the mine collapses on you and you end up dying in the mine. Then the townspeople build a statue of Rusty and then the credits roll...ok I know what your thinking why didn't I mention the townspeople well because all they really do in the game is give you upgrades to your tools.The Gameplay:The gameplay is a mix of Metroid and Minecraft. But what do you do in steamworld dig you mine then sell your ore then go back to the mine then sell and so on. It doesn't sound like much but it's a really addicting game. Like Minecraft the main goal is to well Mine. Like Metroid the game is setup like a maze except you make the path But when you leave the cave it doesn't reset so you need to think out a move before you do it. But there is one major flaw it ends too soon just when your used to everything the game ends with the only boss in the game the voltbot also it takes around 5-6 hours to beat give or take. Yet this is also the best thing in the game too because when you beat the game it posts your score so it makes you destined to come back to beat your last score. Also there's another flaw  which are the side characters they just don't do anything but upgrade your tools. The Verdict:Steamworld dig is one of those masterpieces that comes around every once in a while where a game is so good you always remember the experience you had playing the game. This game is a must have game in anyone's steam library. The game is $9.99 and that is a great price so this game gets a 9.5 out of 10.Pros:+ Great story+ Addictive Gameplay+ Amazing replay value+ Great visuals and soundtrackCons:- Side characters- Length 9.5Must-Have

Posted: July 3, 2014
												It's pretty much Terraria-lite with platforming elements and clearly defined goals. Also without any real combat system. I mean, there's kind of combat, but it's still really hard to defend yourself save for using dynamite. The upgrades you get are generally all good and I was quite happy with how mobile your main character gets by the end of the game; it plays really smoothly, definitely. No control issues at all. My one gripe is that it's really easy to get stuck to a point where you either have to die or keep digging deeper in hopes of finding the one or two teleporters in each area; true, you can bring a teleporter along yourself, but those cost orbs, which are rare and valuable and better used on other upgrades. That aside, it's a fun little exploration platformer, with some decent puzzles to boot. The story's nothing special and almost non-existent, which is really how I like it in a 2D game like this. The final boss is also pretty clever for the type of game this is and makes good use of the mechanics. All in all a delightful but short game that I'd say is probably worth full price, but wait for a sale if you're really tight on money.

Posted: December 8, 2013
												Read the full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/steamworld-dig-game-review/SteamWorld Dig immediately reminded me of Gem Miner, a game for Android-based devices, that I used to play. I had fun with Gem Miner, but SteamWorld Dig vastly improves on the faults of that game, providing me a completely fresh, unique experience. Upon playing through the game, I realized that SteamWorld Dig certainly does justify its standing as a Super Metroid x Terraria hybrid.The main concept in SteamWorld Dig is to, well, dig. You dig/mine through various different types of dirt and rock searching for ore and other treasures. These ores can then be sold at the surface, providing the money needed to purchase upgrades and new equipment at the town’s shop (I should also mention that this town only has three residents, which I found quite amusing). The main character, Rusty, ends up at this town due to the death of his uncle, who owned a mine in the town. Rusty then takes over this mine and has to uncover the secrets of what’s below.Not only are you digging and mining your way through the various objectives in the game, but you also have to watch out for the multitude of enemies hidden below the dirt. A few of them are actually fairly difficult to just ignore, like the guys that throw bottles at you, which damage blocks, although I did use this to my advantage in some scenarios where I was unable to destroy a certain block. I would continuously wall-jump off of the block I wanted destroyed while the bottle-throwing badguy destroyed it for me, missing me every throw.The visuals in the game are far superior to the 3DS version and are a treat to look at. The characters and backgrounds were great and really added to the immersion. The ore textures seemed a bit off to me, however. You cannot tell what material is contained within the ore until you mine it, which I found a bit annoying. All of the ore textures were the same, but there were a variety of minerals and gems dropped from them. The variety of drops was awesome, some of which I’ve never heard of (as they’re probably made-up). The game’s audio was also excellent, no complaints there.The game has a story to it, and although it may be minute, it still exists. The story does progress at a very rapid pace, as the game is quite short, only taking me about three hours to finish. It was an enjoyable experience nonetheless, and I highly recommend it.SteamWorld Dig had a few annoying mechanics that I should mention. There was one instance in the game where it was impossible to progress without getting hit, from my observations. I was stuck in this situation with a sliver of health left and I couldn’t progress. I had to go back and get some health before I could pass. There was another instance where I kept getting myself trapped under boulders, but that’s probably due to my own stupidity!Overall, SteamWorld Dig is a short, enjoyable experience, combining factors from Gem Miner, Terraria, and Super Metroid. It executes this well, combining the gameplay aspects of the three with great graphics and sound. It may lack in replayability, but it still is a worthwhile experience.
