Posted: December 14, 2013
												Steamworld Dig is one of those games that you enjoy for a couple days, and then move onto something else without much of a thought. It's a western, steampunk dig-em-up. Meaning you are part cowboy and part robot and you're going to dig. Dig dig dig. So you can get ore to get money to get upgrades that make it easier to, you guessed it, DIG. Luckily, it's not too tedious as you have to manage your resources, fight enemies, and watch your tunnels to make sure you've got a way out. That third aspect is diminished somewhat by the end of the game when you unlock powerups that make it unnecessary to plan things out, but it does give a sense of progression.It's also broken up with platforming challenges... well platforming exercises. Nothing in this game is terribly challenging. Even death just means a loss of money and going back down to your death bed to pick up your items. However, it's fun enough to be worth playing and short enough not to drag on. I'd reccomend.

Posted: November 13, 2014
												The game was clearly inspired by the great old flash game Motherload (which is still available to play for free if you want an idea of what to expect).  The genre goes back even further to the 80s arcade classic Dig Dug.  The general idea is to dig deep into the earth and uncover treasures so you can return to the surface and buy fancy upgrades so you can dig even further.A few of the mechanics are different (in Motherload you used up "fuel" to fly which let you return to the surface, here the fuel provides lighting and you wall jump to go back up; Motherload's currency was just cash, here there's also special orbs needed for some upgrades).  The characters and art style are great.  My only frustration was some difficulty in landing jumps without slipping off things.  I wish you could stick the landing a bit more. Posted: February 24, 2014
												SteamWorld Dig is fantastic dig-sell-upgrade-dig platformer. It is easy to compare it to Terraria because it is 2D and you dig, but there is a lot more to it than that. First, the platforming  feels perfect. Your gem-hungry robot pilots like Super Meat Boy, easily jumping up walls and performing acrobatic maneuvers, making it a blast to navigate the mines. Second, the pacing is superb. You find and purchase fun upgrades constantly from start to finish. Though it is fairly short and may not have the replayability or depth of the Terarria series, I enjoyed every minute and would highly recommend it to anyone.

Posted: February 24, 2014
												SteamWorld Dig is an excellent combination of Motherlode and platformer.  It has plenty to explore, puzzles to figure out, difficulty where it needs it, a great atmosphere, and fun storyline/characters.  The game has basically everything you could want, except for gametime.  I beat it in a little less than three hours, total.  Now, it does have some random generation to it, and multiple save slots that help with replayability (Not to mention some achievements to go back for) so it's still pretty good for another time around!

Posted: February 9, 2014
												SteamWorld Dig is an enjoyable exploration game with bright visuals and fun playability. You control Rusty, a little robot that's come to take over his Uncle's Mine. It starts off innocently enough as you mine for gems to make some money, but the deeper you get, weirder things start showing up. The controls are great; I played with an XBox controller so I can't vouch for keyboard. The gameplay ranges from exploration to a bit of action, to a fair amount of platforming. Throughout the game you buy upgrades that allow you to do a lot more, giving the game a Metroid or Castlevania-esque feel at times. SteamWorld Dig isn't the longest game; there's an achievement for beating it in under two hours. (Though I imagine that's a hard cheevo to get.) My playthrough took five, but I was hellbent on digging up as much gold as I could. It's very enjoyable for what it is, and I could see myself returning to it again for another playthrough.

Posted: April 9, 2015
												A reasonably fun digging game, although a game where you spend 97% of you time digging with no real purpose can feel kind of dull. The actual digging part resembles Terraria, although instead of the different varieties of ore found in Terraria, Steamworld Dig just has gem nodes that give you junk to exchange for gold. Unlike Terraria, the stuff you gather while digging doesn't have any real use. You just trade it for gold and use that gold to upgrade your digging capabilities. So that you can dig faster, get more gold, and use it to buy more upgrades. Perhaps this is a deep meditation on the pointlessness of consumerism. Or maybe its just kinda dull gameplay.Towards the end of the game, there are caves that feature something resembling puzzles, although none of those puzzles are particularly puzzling. They still make for a nice break from the previous ~4 hours of largely uninterrupted digging. Aside the from the general tedium of the gameplay, my major complaint is the death penalty. You lose half the gold you're carrying every time you die. And because there are only a limited number of gem nodes, you can only get so much gold during the game. If you die more than a few times, you will not be able to afford all the upgrades. This ultimately doesn't really matter, since the upgrades just make you dig faster or die less. But not being able to get everything is frustrating. The story is mostly non-existent, with a random conclusion thrown in at the very end. The narrative certainly won't keep you going if you find the gameplay dull.Overall, I mostly enjoyed Steamworld Dig even with all my complaints. This is probably just because I tend to enjoy tedium in games if it comes along with a sense of progress. If you enjoyed the mining aspects of Terreria, you may like this game. If you like grinding in JRPGs just to make your characters' numbers bigger, you may like this game. However, if you want exciting action or a compelling story, Steamworld Dig is not for you. I would give Steamworld Dig a 6.5/10 and recommend it only if you like digging.

Posted: December 11, 2014
												SteamWorld Dig reminded me a lot of Mario Brothers or Megaman. The ability to dig through most of the map is really satisfying, especially late in the game when you have the digging tool upgrades. The comments of the NPC vendors actually hint at the ending of the story so that when it happens there is a forehead slapping moment of revelation, which I enjoyed.The game is open sandbox. You can go back to any previous area and play more. So if you miss anything you can always backtrack and get it. As you progress, you will find the previous areas are much easier to play, which can help if you got stuck anywhere.The Vendor narrations get annoying. As you scroll through each item, they start narrating immediately. And it's just gibberish and starts sounding like a Skyllex concert if you scroll quickly. It's just a minor thing.The resource management in this game is tremendously fun. You have a lot of limited tools and end up searching for water because you need it to power some of the things you can do. It really makes the game feel steampunk.Naturally I want more. The game started to feel a little repetitious near the end. But for the 4$ Black Friday sale, I can't complain! What I'm saying is that I'm REALLY looking forward to a sequel with more features and I would certainly be willing to pay more for it. This was a really good game. It just felt like Megaman 1. I know there is a lot more that could be done with it.The game is relatively short, moreso because I couldn't put it down. I beleive I beat the game in 6 hours over 3 sittings. I am sure I missed a few things and it's a game that later I will go back and play again. Unfortunately because of the repetitive nature of things near the end, I'll want a little break before I do that.The ending felt a little short. Maybe it's all my time struggling with games like Megaman, but I figured out how to defeat the end boss immediaely and made short work of him. I haven't even checked to see if there are different difficulty modes. If not, that would be a good upgrade.I would have like just a little more at the end of the game. Many games do this. You defeat the boss and the screen fades to black and the game is over. I would like to need to leave the room, with the option of wandering around the dungoen a bit more before having to enter a portal, gate, push a button or do some other activity that would end the game and start the end game sequence.A lot of work was put into this game. I didn't notice any bugs or problems. The music was good. The game play was really good. The teleport system for getting into and out of the dungeon wasn't too easy or too hard. It was a good balance. The game had a built in solution for getting stuck, which was probably possible but never happened to me, in the way of a self destruct in the menu options. That's just smart programing.If you like side scrollers, give this one a try. It's unique, western steampunk fun.

Posted: December 7, 2014
												SteamWorld Dig is a fun little game that blends Metroidvania-esque ability progression with the platforming and money management of a mining game. You play a robot drawn to a dusty Western mining town, who discovers his miner uncle has died and left him a hole in the ground. Your goal: get to the bottom of it.The game has a great visual style and I found the core mechanics engaging, if more than a little repetitive. It was fun for a playthrough. However, I don't think it's a home run game.My first complaint is the story. The world of SteamWorld Dig is a neat one--a world where steam-powered robots are the dominant civilization, and some untold catastrophe has left humans trapped under the earth. But the driving plot of the game is thin to the point of being unsubstantial. Supposedly, you dig deeper in order to figure out just what your uncle was up to, but as a player, I didn't care a lick about that. I was digging just to dig.A more compelling plot would have provided me with reason to care about my uncle and what he found. Since the mechanics of the game encourage an obsession with digging deeper, tying an insatiable urge to dig into the character of the uncle would have made him more sympathetic, and caused the story to resonate better with the gameplay. As it stands, I entirely ignored the "plot" of the game, and I feel the lack of a story detracted from the experience.Secondly, SteamWorld Dig seems to me to have very little replay value. Your mileage may vary if you're inspired by achievements and the idea of speedrunning, but for me, once I reached the bottom, attained all the various skills, and maxed out most of my stats, I had no reason to play the game again. That's because the game's progression is almost entirely linear, with very few challenges requiring backtracking or use of your new abilities (as one might expect from a Metroidvania game). What's more, unless you are very bad at money management, there are next to no branching options for character development in the game; you can upgrade your pickaxe and your other tools and other attributes, without ever having to choose a trade-off. And given the finite amount of resources in the game, there's very little point to returning to a finished game for more mining--eventually, you will have mined all there is to mine.This could have been solved in a number of ways. Inserting more optional high-level challenges at the beginning of the game would reward backtracking and would make the acquisition of new skills feel like more of an accomplishment. Offering more upgrade options, or otherwise making stat boosting feel like more of a meaningful choice, would reward playing through multiple times to experience different "builds". And a New Game+ mode that added new or more difficult enemies and additional challenges would have brought a welcome amount of replay value.This isn't to say SteamWorld Dig is a bad game. Like I said, I enjoyed it when I was playing it. But I think it's a thin game--good for a few hours of enjoyment, but not anything worth returning to once you've finished it.Final rating: 6/10

Posted: May 6, 2014
Click Here for the Full Review! [monthsbehindreviews.blogspot.com]Synopsis: An interesting blend of DigDug and Metroid, where you drill and pickaxe your way through strata, grabbing ores and gems as you go, making your way from cave to cave in search of upgrades and the reason why your deceased uncle left you a mining claim in a town with a population of 3. Back topside you can sell your goods for cash, which you can use to buy additional incremental upgrades for the major ones you've found in your travels.It's a fun little game, though it does have it's quirks. Some of the navigating can be tricky, such as wall jumping, and you can't dig upwards at a diagonal, so be careful you don't get stuck, because having to self destruct (or any other death) means losing half your cash and dropping all your loot (this last bit can be recovered). Worth your time, which won't be much because the speed achievement requires you to beat it in around 2 hours (it took my 7, but I grabbed all the loot, and died more than a few times from digging under a rock). I'd suggest getting it around $2.50, and enjoying a sadly brief respite from Real Life (c) problems. I give it an 8/10.

Posted: September 16, 2014
												I like the fact how simple this game is, you can grasp all the main concepts in a few minutes. Still, even though being that simple, it is very much enjoyable. Especially for us, collectors and perfectionists, it's very charming to be able to dig through the world and try to find every single last precious ore nugget that is out there.The game length is 6 - 10 hours, and that's a benefit for me. The worlds were quite different and they introduced new concepts, which is great, one would never feel bored.The only thing I disliked about this game is the "light" game concept. It seems to be that it was introduced in order to make the game less plain, to make the game mechanics more complex. Which I agree with, it would be way too simple otherwise. But it's not designed properly. With current design, you simply have to go above ground every few minutes, even though your bag is almost empty and you have no other reason to return, just to refill the light lamp. That often means spending up to several minutes traversing the mine to the top. That's crazy, and it's annoying as hell. Some possible improvements to this concept include: a) an ability to refill the oil from the (eternal) lamps scattered through the level, maybe at the expense of extinguishing that lamp forever b) an ability to purchase and take with you an extra flask of oil, maybe even at the expense of one of the inventory slots. With this approach, you have immediately made the game less painful and also more interesting, because there is very interesting choice to be had - spend more money and have less inventory space, but have longer and more convenient light? Those are exactly the right tough question every game should offer. Sadly, in this case, it was not though out well.Except for the single issue mentioned above, I very much enjoyed how the game looked and played, and recommend it to everyone enjoying this kind of casual exploring/digging/a bit puzzle and platforming genre.

Posted: November 24, 2014
												I think I got this in an Indie game bundle for Humble Bundle, and I played a few other of the games in it and wasn't really impressed, so I didn't get to playing this.Well, now I'm visiting my parents with my somewhat old laptop and decided it looked like fun. Well it's 3 am now and I am happy to report that it is pretty fun.It takes some elements from an old favorite of mine "Motherload" and I think it puts it's own twist on the "mining platform" genre (?)I really liked the progression, I think it was well paced. I never felt too underpowered but I always felt that there was a goal to be reached, and I think that the timing of the abilities was well done as well as the introduction of new shops that made it feel like a real accomplishment when you bought all of the upgrades from a store.The different stages were nice, it again added to the progression. Though I do think that the enemies should have been slightly more specialized for each area. Like the basic melee enemy, which was the worm and the shiners. Instead of having them just hit you and bounce off, it would have added a little variety by making the shiner actively attack you when you get near them. The enemies seemed a little to basic in general, usually only having 2 or 3 enemies per stage, which got a little repeatative but the environment helped keep things interesting overall. The puzzle and ability rooms were well done, not too simple, and making you feel like you are missing something, making you look for a way to get to a certain ore or something. It was nice. Basic platforming done well in my opinion. Though the secret areas contained within the rooms were very easy to see, so it wasn't very gratifying to find them.Overall I think this is a very nicely done game. I felt the progression is very well done, the environment was interesting, and it is a fair game. However, I feel like there could have been a little more enemy variety, the music isn't great, and my god the characters' voices make me want to punch a baby seal in the face. If there were a slider or box for their "voice" I would have been less happy that I could skip their dialogue and I might have actually read what they were saying.I apologize for any spelling or grammatical errors that may be present.TL;DR progression and environment are great. Can be a little too repeatative and the overworld characters' "voices" are annoying as ****.

												This is a fun little platformer type game. Due to upgrades you get, you could say it is a metroidvania type game.You start out with nothing and are dropped into the underground caves of a town. You a local, and are told about you uncle. Shortly after, you get you first item, a pick axe.The game revolves around using digging devices (throughout the game you find more) to keep mining the gems under the town and fend off enimies. While there are enimies, that isn't the highlight of the game. You keep getting upgrades of your digging devices as well throughout the game.If you die, you drop all the gems you are carring and are returned to town. You loose 50% of your gold as well, so you want to avoid this. The first time through you might find yourself digging down faster than you should. It is wise to plan ahead so you can always get back up to sell those precious gems.While at first there might not be much stratigy, as stated above you do need to be careful just digging down and fast. Plan ahead, so you have tunnels that you can use to your advantage. Thera are consumable's you can use to help out, but I found them not very useful. I found spending my money on upgrades more worth the money.There are 3 diffrent "types" of mning areas you go through. They get progresivly harder to mine, but the game overall isn't very challanging.Overall I would recomend the game. I also feel it is sutable for the younger crowd if you are looking for your children. I played the game completly with a wireless xbox 360 controler, and had no issues with it. I do now know how a KBAM would be.

Posted: December 16, 2013
												SteamWorld Dig is very charming and a lot of fun. Many people as whether or not the game is similar to 'Terraria', and the answer is no. If you were to compare SteamWorld Dig to any other game I think the closest would be Motherlode - the old(ish) Flash title that was popular on Miniclip. You go underground, you dig for minerals, you return to the surface to drop them off and make money to purchase new upgrades in order to dig for more minerals, more effectively. It's simple, but the game's constant introduction of new mechanics keep it challenging and interesting. In 2013, where there are so many games out there that focus on exploration that give the player a degree of sandbox freedom, it is fair to wonder whether or not a game like this will gather a large fanbase. In a sandbox game, the exploration and gathering of materials feels a little bit more organic than in Steamworld Dig, where you really only have a few options for upgrades and the resources are essentially melted down into the same currency. SteamWorld has no intention of being that kind of organic exploration/survival title though, but people will still draw that comparison and I am sure that there are people that will find fault with that. If you're looking for a game that fits that description, SteamWorld is not for you.I have two main faults with the game. First, the PC port does not allow for the rebinding of keys. I am usually pretty lax when it comes to crucifying a game for being a lackluster port but not giving me the ability to re-bind keys is a pretty big issue - especially when the game uses up, down, left, right as the movement controls and not WASD, meaning some gamers with 'gaming' keyboards (such as the Logitech G510) will run into input conflicts. I found myself using an Xbox 360 controller and a third party program, which I think benefited the game, but is still inexcusable. Second, the length. I beat Steamworld in 3.5 hours according to my save file, and I am by no means a good gamer. For $9.99, that isn't entirely damning of the game, but it does leave you wanting more. There are plenty of achievements that encourage replay, though.

Posted: December 8, 2013
												Read the full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/steamworld-dig-game-review/SteamWorld Dig immediately reminded me of Gem Miner, a game for Android-based devices, that I used to play. I had fun with Gem Miner, but SteamWorld Dig vastly improves on the faults of that game, providing me a completely fresh, unique experience. Upon playing through the game, I realized that SteamWorld Dig certainly does justify its standing as a Super Metroid x Terraria hybrid.The main concept in SteamWorld Dig is to, well, dig. You dig/mine through various different types of dirt and rock searching for ore and other treasures. These ores can then be sold at the surface, providing the money needed to purchase upgrades and new equipment at the town’s shop (I should also mention that this town only has three residents, which I found quite amusing). The main character, Rusty, ends up at this town due to the death of his uncle, who owned a mine in the town. Rusty then takes over this mine and has to uncover the secrets of what’s below.Not only are you digging and mining your way through the various objectives in the game, but you also have to watch out for the multitude of enemies hidden below the dirt. A few of them are actually fairly difficult to just ignore, like the guys that throw bottles at you, which damage blocks, although I did use this to my advantage in some scenarios where I was unable to destroy a certain block. I would continuously wall-jump off of the block I wanted destroyed while the bottle-throwing badguy destroyed it for me, missing me every throw.The visuals in the game are far superior to the 3DS version and are a treat to look at. The characters and backgrounds were great and really added to the immersion. The ore textures seemed a bit off to me, however. You cannot tell what material is contained within the ore until you mine it, which I found a bit annoying. All of the ore textures were the same, but there were a variety of minerals and gems dropped from them. The variety of drops was awesome, some of which I’ve never heard of (as they’re probably made-up). The game’s audio was also excellent, no complaints there.The game has a story to it, and although it may be minute, it still exists. The story does progress at a very rapid pace, as the game is quite short, only taking me about three hours to finish. It was an enjoyable experience nonetheless, and I highly recommend it.SteamWorld Dig had a few annoying mechanics that I should mention. There was one instance in the game where it was impossible to progress without getting hit, from my observations. I was stuck in this situation with a sliver of health left and I couldn’t progress. I had to go back and get some health before I could pass. There was another instance where I kept getting myself trapped under boulders, but that’s probably due to my own stupidity!Overall, SteamWorld Dig is a short, enjoyable experience, combining factors from Gem Miner, Terraria, and Super Metroid. It executes this well, combining the gameplay aspects of the three with great graphics and sound. It may lack in replayability, but it still is a worthwhile experience.

Posted: December 5, 2013
												Do not let my short time with this version mislead you; whereas, I have destroyed the 3DS version of this game and found myself surprisingly hooked for hours.  I was pleasantly surprised to notice this on sale today, and purchased it immediately - it's that good.  After only 15 minute on the Steam/PC version, rest assured, the transition is everything it should be.  Here's an actual review of the game itself.  Last, I apologize now for spelling, grammatical, or contextual errors, i.e., I am typing quickly in a dark room~This game is fresh, imaginitive, visually stylish, and is easy to pickup, but requires elements of strategy as you dig and rewards you with progress often.  It delivers a perfect balance; whereas, it is far from super easy, though never hits impossibile or the bang your head against the wall to end it all 'frustration rage' (we've all seen this, be it controllers, walls, friends, etc).  You start casually, but there are no long drawn out tutorials, cut scenses, or credits.  Shorrtly after hitting the start button, you are playing - a feature that is more uncommon than is often noted.  Its apparent almost immediately that the game possesses visually asthetic fluidity.   As you continue to explore, the pacing set by the game is consistently maitained and develops respective to the depths you traverse, and keeps you balanced by means of progressive upgrades, powerups, the twon's growth, purchasable items, and increased value of the loot you find. This game constantly rewards you and creates the sense of wanting to play just a bit longer.  I found myself setting aside some of lifes responaibilities simply because I enjoyed the time I spent playing, e.g., foolhardily making the wife wait longer than any wife prefers to wait...multiple times (Protip: AVOID this mistake).  Additionally, the balance feels very natural and honestly has a rare bit of brillance that you never really think about, probably because it does play so well.  The time you spend jmping through the air, punching, digging, upgrading your items, treking back to town, while thinking about how youre going to get all the way back to the pipe/teleporter as you make some questionable wall jumps never really got old; rather, it did feel as though you accomplished and understand the game more.  As the game tosses new dynamics this feeling continued to evolve... and I found myself enjoying it as I evolved as a player.  Despite the hollistic theme of digging, digging, digging, the gameplay never really got old.  It all comes together in a package that delivers an experience that really ends up complimeting the multiple componets of its own gameplay; therfore, bringing itself together delivering syle, balance, exploration, while provinding a (gamer's) sense of accomplishment, excitment, and fun -> a feeling often associated with video games; however, is all too often replaced with a sense of obligation to finish simply becasue we started or have put so much into it.  This gam never created a sense of obligation, and if your a gamer you know the feeling I am referring to.  This game transcends that dynamic and sccomplishes the ever more difficult task of creating the fundemtntial elements of enjoyment.  This game is appropriate for gamers of all ages, styles, and skill level(s).  The constant rewards will develop younger players, yet can offer old school gamers (the one's who grew up on arcades/atari/nes/collecovison) an experience that is a often more difficult to find in a game.  Buy it.  You will literally find yourself digging in~

Posted: October 7, 2014
												A post-apocalyptic tale (with Old West influences) of a robot who goes into a mine to continue the work of his robot uncle. You dig down, look for minerals, and unravel the mystery of how your relative disappeared. This is a simple side-scrolling platformer with some RPG elements, but a worthwhile one. It's paced nicely, the gameplay is good, the art and characters are interesting, etc. To beat the game it requires about 3-9 hours of playtime depending on how much you explore and how many upgrades you want (personally I don't mind grinding but others may disagree). SteamWorld Dig is a bit lighthearted and casual, but it's not a yawnsome breeze to play either. You'll probably encounter a few parts here and there that are semi-challenging. Nothing serious of course, but it was nice to see some level of strategy beyond "point and click anywhere to win."I'm not sure if the game is worth $10 - maybe a bit closer to $5 - but it's well done. 8/10, like Metacritic says, seems accurate. Not the best game ever, but it's pretty fun and worth a try. I got this in a Humble Bundle and it's definitely worth more than what I paid.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Steamworld Dig is a quirky game. It is remenescent of iDigit on the iPhone but with upgrades and some platformer elements (on the set levels). For most of the game you just dig deeper in your grandfather's mine to collect rescources to sell at the town. In the beggining you have little tools and abilities, but within a few minutes you will unlock abilities like dash and super jump. The graphics are remeniscent of the 16-32 bit era but are rendered in HD. The game is simple with only three stats that you need to keep up with: health, Fire and water (the later two being used up as a varation of a mana bar). The game is slightly humorous and keeps the player entertained while also holding the player's hand.

												This game reminds me when I would come home from school and sit down and play Motherload on Miniclip.com for hours - This game is like that but so much better; way better graphics just as much if not more fun and it has a sort of mineshaft thing which I guess is like a dungeon of sorts which is what was missing from Motherload so it didn’t get boring after a few hours. Posted: December 14, 2014
												The good: This is a fun little game to keep you entertained for the afternoon. The story is decent for the type of game it is, the graphics are cute, and the gameplay is a fun exercise in logistics as you try to mine ores and avoid enemies. The music is good and sets the tone well. The game has an achievement for finishing with speed and an achievement for being a completionist, so there is some replay value through different styles of play. The bad: The controls are somewhat finnicky, especially the wall jump. I had several frustrating slides and long periods of being stuck in deep mine shafts and unable to climb out. The story is also very short. It depends on how fast of a gamer you are, but there's actually an achievement for finishing the entire game in under 2.5 hours, so that tells you how quick it can go. That good music I mentioned can also get a little repetitive. General info: You play this game as a little steam-powered robot; you dig ores in a mine and sell them to get upgrades for your gear. This isn't a heavy duty type game; more of a light entertainment. It's an easy game to pick up and put down and come back to later, which is nice somtimes. Overall: It's a fun little game. Not sure it's worth the full price, but if you can catch it during a sale, I definitely think it's worth getting. I enjoyed it quite a bit.System Specs Used: Intel Core i7-3610QM, Nvidia GeForce GTX 670M / 3GB GDDR5, DDRIII 12GB RAM, Windows 7

Posted: December 14, 2014
												I love this game, it seems as though it's just an exploring game like terraria, but the story line is so gripping. Usually I get bored of games after a while and play it after some other games, but after 1 run of FTL, I couldn't think of anything but playing this game there was almost nothing I hated about it... and then...(Disclaimer, this is not a spoiler, although it may seem like it, there is no hinting to what the end IS.) The ending, I love ends of games due to the fact that practically anything can happen. But when I completed it, I knew what the 1 drawback to this game was, once you finished the ending... It started from the last save... THE LAST SAVE! There's no after the ending, you just get to play through the ending over and over again until you make a new save... So overall I'd give this game an 8/10... so I would recommend this game, but it's not my all time favorite...

Posted: December 21, 2014
												A short but fun game. You play as a robot as he mines his way down to the bottom of the World. The gameplay is fun. It is kind of like Terraria except you travel back to the surface frequently to sell ores to buy pickaxe upgrades/ a larger bag. Its simplistic, but generally fun. The game would get old if it was longer than 4 hours to beat and the challenge increases nicely. There are a few flaws. Firstly, you will need to travel to the surface frequently and teleporters back are not common enough (you can buy your own but they cost orbs which you need to collect for the best upgrades). Secondly, there are a handful of blind drops which you will need close to full health to survive. Spoiler warning:Finally the game ends with a boss fight and the combat in the game is really not its strong point. Overall, not a bad way to waste an evening. Worth picking up in a sale.

 I recommend this game immensely. first playthrough 8 hours, Second playthrough 4 hours. All of a sudden I'm playing to get the master prospector achievement which I did get. This is the only game that really had me coming back to beat my highscore. The Master Prospector achievement is -   Beat the game in less than 2 and a half hours   Make $20,000 Dollars or more   Collecting 150 or more orbs  You can only die once Getting this achievement was really frustaring but well worth it in the end. I don't know if it's the collecting ore, upgrading and digging but this game had me hooked. This game made me want to %100 the game and I accomplished that. You should get this game honestly the best $11 I have spent for the most fun.

Posted: April 4, 2015
												For first, this game looks A-W-E-S-O-M-E! Like, it is a feast for my eyes, even just lookin' to the game is entertaining for me. +1 from there.The mechanics of the game is really cool, Terrarria-Minecraft like mining, and then comes the fun part, platform. It is really cool and enjoyable but don't expect much more. +1 indeed.And since your going to mine, you must be careful and plan every step you'll make. As you go deeper you must set a road for you back there to climb back up, there are some thingys for you to make your journey easy but -If you are dumb like me- you can fail easily. And if you fail, you'll be regenerate outside of the mine with losing all your stuff. It's kinda rough-like and It's very very cool adds tansion to the game. Another +1.And It's wild west themed! Posted: March 7, 2016
												     Steamworld dig was a strange but fun experience. Its not exactly a 2D platformer, because the precision and combat that take place take a backseat to a slower thoughtful game. The player must descend into the earth (hence "Dig"), but the route must be strategic so that one can explore the cave, reach resources, and most critically, not carelessly dig oneself into a grave.     The planning and excavation feels pleasantly fresh, but can often lead to frustration for those as impatient as myself when you realize you've gone too far, and may never be able to reach that critical resource beyond the reach of your pickaxe. On the other hand, it does make thoroughness feel all the more rewarding, especially considering that a majority of the upgrades have meaningful impacts on how you play the game and what you can accomplish.      It isn't a game that I could binge, but all its clever ideas deserve to be appreciated between the aliens we've been gunning down for decades.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												Not sure why I enjoyed this game so much.  I suppose it just didn't have any glaring flaws.-Controls are tight and responsive-Clear indications of what you're supposed to be doing without being annoying or insulting-Good difficulty curve-Progression feels rewardingTo vastly oversimplify it, it's like a stripped down, more focused version of Terraria.  All the fluff, crafting, creating of Terraria is removed and replaced with a progression system and a much more streamlined digging and ore-finding experience. While this game does seem to have replayability for achievements and such, you can suspect a much shorter experience with SteamWorld Dig (about 4 hours for a leisurely playthrough vs whatever 600 hours I've dumped on Terraria).

												I'll say that I like robots and that I like the wild west. It has both so I can't complain. Steamworld Dig is a great mining game with several influences such as Terarria, Megaman and Metroid. You play as Rusty who has inherited an old mine from his uncle. The main objective is to mine, collect ores, sell them and reach for the bottem of the mine. It was originally released on 3DS and the game is quite appealing to the eye, they managed to add quite a bit of colour for a mining game which is nice. The music is decent but I wouldn't say catchy. It more melds right into the game which is great as it adds to the game. The mining in the game is all about risk versus reward and it is done quite superbly.Overall I give it 8.5/10 Its fun, looks great and you can play the game in your own pace. If you're not a big fan of games like Minecraft or Terraria, you should at least give this a go because (for people like me) it has a story and an ending plus the game has a bit to offer.

Posted: December 14, 2014
												The good: This is a fun little game to keep you entertained for the afternoon. The story is decent for the type of game it is, the graphics are cute, and the gameplay is a fun exercise in logistics as you try to mine ores and avoid enemies. The music is good and sets the tone well. The game has an achievement for finishing with speed and an achievement for being a completionist, so there is some replay value through different styles of play. The bad: The controls are somewhat finnicky, especially the wall jump. I had several frustrating slides and long periods of being stuck in deep mine shafts and unable to climb out. The story is also very short. It depends on how fast of a gamer you are, but there's actually an achievement for finishing the entire game in under 2.5 hours, so that tells you how quick it can go. That good music I mentioned can also get a little repetitive. General info: You play this game as a little steam-powered robot; you dig ores in a mine and sell them to get upgrades for your gear. This isn't a heavy duty type game; more of a light entertainment. It's an easy game to pick up and put down and come back to later, which is nice somtimes. Overall: It's a fun little game. Not sure it's worth the full price, but if you can catch it during a sale, I definitely think it's worth getting. I enjoyed it quite a bit.System Specs Used: Intel Core i7-3610QM, Nvidia GeForce GTX 670M / 3GB GDDR5, DDRIII 12GB RAM, Windows 7

												8/10 It is a very addicting game with fun gameplay, making it a bargain for the cheap price it costs.

Posted: December 11, 2014
												SteamWorld Dig reminded me a lot of Mario Brothers or Megaman. The ability to dig through most of the map is really satisfying, especially late in the game when you have the digging tool upgrades. The comments of the NPC vendors actually hint at the ending of the story so that when it happens there is a forehead slapping moment of revelation, which I enjoyed.The game is open sandbox. You can go back to any previous area and play more. So if you miss anything you can always backtrack and get it. As you progress, you will find the previous areas are much easier to play, which can help if you got stuck anywhere.The Vendor narrations get annoying. As you scroll through each item, they start narrating immediately. And it's just gibberish and starts sounding like a Skyllex concert if you scroll quickly. It's just a minor thing.The resource management in this game is tremendously fun. You have a lot of limited tools and end up searching for water because you need it to power some of the things you can do. It really makes the game feel steampunk.Naturally I want more. The game started to feel a little repetitious near the end. But for the 4$ Black Friday sale, I can't complain! What I'm saying is that I'm REALLY looking forward to a sequel with more features and I would certainly be willing to pay more for it. This was a really good game. It just felt like Megaman 1. I know there is a lot more that could be done with it.The game is relatively short, moreso because I couldn't put it down. I beleive I beat the game in 6 hours over 3 sittings. I am sure I missed a few things and it's a game that later I will go back and play again. Unfortunately because of the repetitive nature of things near the end, I'll want a little break before I do that.The ending felt a little short. Maybe it's all my time struggling with games like Megaman, but I figured out how to defeat the end boss immediaely and made short work of him. I haven't even checked to see if there are different difficulty modes. If not, that would be a good upgrade.I would have like just a little more at the end of the game. Many games do this. You defeat the boss and the screen fades to black and the game is over. I would like to need to leave the room, with the option of wandering around the dungoen a bit more before having to enter a portal, gate, push a button or do some other activity that would end the game and start the end game sequence.A lot of work was put into this game. I didn't notice any bugs or problems. The music was good. The game play was really good. The teleport system for getting into and out of the dungeon wasn't too easy or too hard. It was a good balance. The game had a built in solution for getting stuck, which was probably possible but never happened to me, in the way of a self destruct in the menu options. That's just smart programing.If you like side scrollers, give this one a try. It's unique, western steampunk fun.

Steamworld Dig is a great mining game with several influences such as Terarria, Megaman and Metroid. You play as Rusty who has inherited an old mine from his uncle. The main objective is to mine, collect ores, sell them and reach for the bottem of the mine. It was originally released on 3DS and the game is quite appealing to the eye, they managed to add quite a bit of colour for a mining game which is nice. The music is decent but I wouldn't say catchy. It more melds right into the game which is great as it adds to the game. The mining in the game is all about risk versus reward and it is done quite superbly.Overall I give it 8.5/10 Its fun, looks great and you can play the game in your own pace. If you're not a big fan of games like Minecraft or Terraria, you should at least give this a go because (for people like me) it has a story and an ending plus the game has a bit to offer.

Posted: July 16, 2016
												The game is quite fun and gives around seven hours of gameplay but only if you take it slow and want to explorer everything. This is basically the old “Motherlode” game from miniclip.com as you just go deeper and deeper while mining everything you find. The added twist here are the explorable caves which will then require you to solve a puzzle, which are really the fun part of the game as going down in a straight line does get a bit boring after a while. Art style is really well done as are the different characters and their dialogue. Game is best played by using a controller, although this isn't natively supported. I used a freeware program like Joy To Key to bind the input of my controller to the keybindigs of the game after which it played much better. The biggest negative about this game was the disappointing end boss, really easy and just lazy game design.Overall I would only recommend buying this game if it is on sale as it lacks a satisfying amount of playable hours.

Posted: March 7, 2016
												     Steamworld dig was a strange but fun experience. Its not exactly a 2D platformer, because the precision and combat that take place take a backseat to a slower thoughtful game. The player must descend into the earth (hence "Dig"), but the route must be strategic so that one can explore the cave, reach resources, and most critically, not carelessly dig oneself into a grave.     The planning and excavation feels pleasantly fresh, but can often lead to frustration for those as impatient as myself when you realize you've gone too far, and may never be able to reach that critical resource beyond the reach of your pickaxe. On the other hand, it does make thoroughness feel all the more rewarding, especially considering that a majority of the upgrades have meaningful impacts on how you play the game and what you can accomplish.      It isn't a game that I could binge, but all its clever ideas deserve to be appreciated between the aliens we've been gunning down for decades.

Posted: December 31, 2014
												PROS:  This game has a good rewards system and sometimes you may feel surprised because of the enemies that come out of the rocks. Also I like the Drill! The drill helps you drill through rock faster and get where you need to go, it's a great power up in the game. Also this game carries alot of upgrades for your Pick Ax, Water Supply and much more. This is a good game for casual and serious gamers. The gameplay looks nice and cartoony. It also has few NPC's which could be a bad thing but it allows them to stand out and become a big part of the game. CONS: This game is short, more content would of been nice. It is also hard to know what to do next if there isn't a big red dot on the map. The upgrades in the game could of gotten more use but was neglected. After you beat the game, it is quite bland and unrewarding. Money is scares and can't be brought back which is intresting but hard when you know you need big upgrades for the Final Boss.INCONCLUSION: This game is nice but very short and would be better with more content. This game is for you if you want a nice story with decent gameplay. This game isn't for you if you want a long story and don't like limited use of upgrades.7.3/10

Posted: February 16, 2016
												Ok so full disclosure I haven't played this game fully on steam but have recently purchased on xbox and racked up about 15 hours on xbox which should go to show you how great this game. Overall your playing as a robot with other robots trying to revive a town and find what your uncle was working on. Overall the story gets lost really. All you need to know is that you dig and along the way you pick up some sci fi powerups your uncle found and try to figure what is buried down there. In reality if you got the mineral radar before hand this game would be signifigantly shorter as there are only 3 worlds and is my one big complaint about this game because it is so fun I wanted to keep on playing but seeing as this developer only has one game I hope the capital they gain from this game will allow them to make longer games in the future. Overall the mining is where it is at as you can dig side to sidse or down but you gotta be careful because you can't dig upwards easily or at all in some places if you screw up and you can't get the exact angle. You carry a latern which goes by 60 second intervals so you gotta refill it by going to the surface and you can only carry so many minerals. Refilling your minerals will give you money to buy upgrades and passing certain thresholds allows more people to come to town and purchase better upgrade.  Again this game would be a lot shorter and I think the developer realized the mineral radar at the very end. You are given a mini map but your not able to view the whole thing only what your currently right by which can be annoying but it does shows you entrances to places. Honestly for a first game this is very good and definitly worth your purchase. What I hope to see the developer do is expand on this for a possible sequel. Its much like the first portal its very short and leaves you wanting more.  My only other word of caution to the developer is that because minerals don't respawn the only way to heal yourself is money or by farming enemies which can be tedious and dying doesn't refill your health fully. Granted they give you a wide burth but still.  I would pick this up on sale its well worth it

Posted: March 16, 2015
Score: 7/10Similar GamesMetroid and SprelunkySummaryYour uncle has left you the deed to a mine. Your goal is to find out why. You will recieve upgrades tech throughout the game by finding them in the mine as well as buying them with what you find in the mine. Delve deep and find out the mystery.PositiveThe game has very solid pacing. The atmosphere is unique and keeps you interested. The gems you dig up change as you progress. The characters may only speak in text but they are illustrated in a way where you can make it up accents by looking at them. The upgrades come in constantly which is a good thing.NegativeThe game wears thin so it is actually a good thing that it is only about 3.5 hours long. With more enemies and crazier upgrades the game could have been longer, but the real issue is the digging element itself wears thin. The story exists only to progress the game.ConclusionSteamWorld Dig is a solid metroidvania title that you'll enjoy until the end. That end will come rather soon, but it ends when it should. The game is from an unknown so they did a great job for there first game.ValueI got the game in a bundle, but I'd feel solid saying you wouldn't regret paying $3.50 for it at all.

 I recommend this game immensely. first playthrough 8 hours, Second playthrough 4 hours. All of a sudden I'm playing to get the master prospector achievement which I did get. This is the only game that really had me coming back to beat my highscore. The Master Prospector achievement is -   Beat the game in less than 2 and a half hours   Make $20,000 Dollars or more   Collecting 150 or more orbs  You can only die once Getting this achievement was really frustaring but well worth it in the end. I don't know if it's the collecting ore, upgrading and digging but this game had me hooked. This game made me want to %100 the game and I accomplished that. You should get this game honestly the best $11 I have spent for the most fun.
